description.narrative: Builds on its strong member base by further raising awareness of inclusive business practices and contributions to the Sustainable Development Goals; providing recognition to quality practices and supporting companies through tools and training.

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

comment.narrative:
Baseline (EOY 2016)
OUTCOME INDICATORS Outcome A: IB is recognized as an effective approach to achieving the SDGs Recognition of IB as PS contribution to SDG global agenda (Yes/No): To be tracked going forward Indicators to track IB models contribution to the SDGs defined: No indicators defined IB included by leading corporate sustainability standards as a measure of responsible business practices: To be tracked forward
Outcome B: The credibility of IBs' results and integrity is improved Evidence of IB contribution to SDGs improved: To be tracked going forward Number of participating companies that adopt better impact measurement practices through BCtA tools and guidance: 21 participating companies in BIMS Members and other stakeholders perceive improved credibility of IB commitments and BCtA’s membership and impact measurement support: To be tracked going forward through annual surveys
Outcome C: IBs increase their effectiveness and scale Members adopting good IB management practices: No indicators available Number of follow-on commitments: 4 Number of commitments that report growth: 62% (58 /94 companies) reported that their initiatives have grown during the past year. Number of member companies that perceive BCtA tools have helped them improve their effectiveness and scale: To be tracked going forward through member survey
OUTPUT INDICATORS OUTPUT 1: Increased number of high-performing commitments 1.1 Number of potential member companies that BCtA has encouraged to consider IB annually: 200 per year 1.2 Number of new BCtA companies: Total 182 companies (Target: 176) 1.3 Number of BCtA Commitments: Total 186 commitments (Target: 180) 1.4. Online and offline capacity building on SDG/IB Maturity Tool and management practices: To be tracked going forward 1.5 Relevant role at critical global/regional events: At least one yearly global event (Annual Forum) 1.6 Selection process and criteria published: Revised Selection process and criteria in draft 1.7 Hi

Growing our Membership Base Demonstrating the Power of Inclusive Business for the SDGs 1. By June 2019, increase BCtA membership base to 235 companies with high quality, innovative, scalable IB commitments (cumulative target). 2. Continue to build a strong pipeline of potential member companies and encourage them to consider IB models. 3. By June 2019, reach at least 80 companies through online and offline capacity building on the SDG/IB Maturity Tool and management practices. 4. Integrate the Insightly CRM system into everyday outreach and membership work by using it to organize data; track membership communication; identify trends in outreach and inclusive business opportunities; and streamline outreach efforts in general.
BCtA’s country level work 1. Continue to carry out capacity building activities and deploy BCtA tools and services including SDG/IB Maturity Tool and Impact Measurement Tool in Colombia and Bangladesh. 2. In both Colombia and Bangladesh, encourage increased quality in private sector engagement in SDGs through inclusive business, growing BCtA membership in these two countries. 3. Continued engagement on IB and SDGs through knowledge products and advocacy; assess opportunities for further engagement through UNDP private sector events and network, provide relevant policy inputs through IB knowledge products. 4. Build a preliminary road map to roll out our tools and services in Tunisia, including key stakeholders and strategic partners. Building capacity of BCtA Member Companies and Inclusive Business to Measure and Manage Impact 1. 80 companies provided with online and in-person capacity building on impact management 2. At least 50% of member companies share annual progress report by end of July. 3. Collaborate with key players in the SDG measurement space to further advance BCtA’s methodology and approach.
Knowledge management and communication in 2019 1. Position BCtA Secretariat and its member companies as active thought leaders in the field of inclusive business through regular publication and distribution of quality content that addresses leading issues related to IB. 2. Maintain BCtA website as the go-to platform for the latest development and knowledge on IB, with a focus on promoting its range of tool-kits for IB. 3. Continue growing social media audience following and interaction across BCtA accounts to support Objective 2 (above) and reach and engage diverse and strategic online audiences. 4. Advance BCtA knowledge management systems to efficiently capture the explicit and tacit knowledge produced by BCtA, its members, partners and relevant stakeholders, and ensure the strategic use of this knowledge to catalyze learning and evidence.

As of December 31st, BCtA is set to fall below its year 3 membership target with a cumulative total of 249 member companies and 262 IB commitments (including 3 re-commitments) after welcoming 23 new companies. This is largely due to the number of companies which have been held up in their applications by the bottleneck in on-boarding and due diligence. 36 companies are currently drafting or finalizing their applications or have completed them and are waiting for due diligence procedures to be completed. In 2019, 54% of the reports due were submitted by members, which is below the 60% target. This is due to technical issues with the reporting software, which was introduced in 2018. Once these issues are resolved, the reporting proportion is expected to rise. BCtA has continued to provide training to companies, helping them advance on their IB maturity journey and contribution to the SDGs. BCtA training in Berlin (10 companies), London (8), Lagos (19), Cairo (10), Utrecht (20), and Istanbul (3) were accompanied by 137 offline training, such that the target of 150 companies trained was exceeded. BCtA continued to play a significant role in global events, including the organisation of the 9th Annual Forum and participation in the MENA BoP Summit in Cairo and the Tunis Forum on Gender Equality, ii2030. BCtA provided 34 companies with the opportunity to speak at events and share their IB experiences. BCtA has also developed partnerships with UNDP COs and impact accelerator programmes, running training in Armenia, Bangladesh, Belarus, Indonesia, Moldova, and the Philippines with the support on COs. Twenty member companies are continuing on the Impact Champions journey, undertaking a full cycle of impact management with guidance from BCtA. 432 companies started using the Impact Lab (of which 40 percent completed Module 2) and we collaborated with UNDP country offices in Armenia, Bangladesh, Belarus, Indonesia, Moldova, and the Philippines to provide online and in-person impact clinics for 55 companies. A partnership with Impact Hub allowed 48 start-ups to receive training on impact management from BCtA. 37 members were featured in BCtA publications and articles, highlighting their work and results, and 18 of these were co-written by companies. These were then distributed through our partnerships with 3BL Media and The Guardian, which shared 63 stories in 2019. In September, BCtA launched the inclusive management practices tool and published the What does it take to go big? Management practices to bring inclusive business to scale report, which included 17 member case studies. The tool is specifically designed to support MNCs in the identification, characterization, and implementation of their IB objectives, and will include the bench-marking of progress against peers. A thematic focus on gender was promoted with the introduction of 6 gendered reporting targets and gender impact considerations for new members, with 33 member companies now being women-led. From the focus countries, BCtA added six new members in 2019 (two from Bangladesh and four from Colombia). In Colombia, the SDG Corporate Tracker has provided an important service through its standardized structure for assessing companies’ contribution to the achievement of the SDGs. In Tunisia, we have been able to develop a detailed map of the IB ecosystem through scoping following engagement with the CO. This will allow Tunisias addition as a focus country once funding is secured. BCtA also engaged an external expert to conduct a mid-term review of BCtAs activities and value to companies, conducting round-table events in Colombia and online in order to receive and incorporate feedback from members.

Note: 2020 targets were revised and approved by BCtA DSC to accommodate the unprecedented disruption brought by the COVID-19 crisis. OUTCOME LEVEL Outcome A: IB is recognized as an effective approach for achieving the SDGs Indicator: Recognition of IB as PS contribution to SDG global agenda (Yes/No); Baseline (End of Year 2): Yes; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Yes; July – Dec 2020 Target: Yes
Indicator: Indicators to track IB models’ contribution to the SDGs defined; Baseline (End of Year 2): 40 indicators from SDGs developed and integrated into the Impact Lab; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Continued integration; July – Dec 2020 Target: Continued integration
Indicator: IB included by leading corporate sustainability standards as a measure of responsible business practices; Baseline (End of Year 2): Yes; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Yes; July – Dec 2020 Target: Yes
Outcome B: The credibility of IBs results and integrity is improved Indicator: Evidence of IB contribution to SDGs improved; Baseline (End of Year 2): Evidence delivered; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Evidence delivered; July – Dec 2020 Target: Evidence delivered
Indicator: Number of participating companies that adopt better impact measurement practices through BCtA tools and guidance; Baseline (End of Year 2): 91 companies using BCtA’s impact management approach (21 BIMS, 70 companies using the Impact Lab); Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): 130; July – Dec 2020 Target: 155
Indicator: Members and other stakeholders perceive improved credibility of IB commitments and BCtA’s membership and impact measurement support; Baseline (End of Year 2): Achieved; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Achieved; July – Dec 2020 Target: Achieved
Outcome C: IBs increase their effectiveness and scale Indicator: Members adopting good IB management practices; Baseline (End of Year 2): Typology validated; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Track good management practices and assess link with progress made; July – Dec 2020 Target: Track good management practices and assess link with progress made
Indicator: Number of follow-on commitments; Baseline (End of Year 2): -; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): -; July – Dec 2020 Target: -
Indicator: Number of commitments that report growth; Baseline (End of Year 2): 92 percent in 2017 reporting; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): -; July – Dec 2020 Target: -
Indicator: Number of member companies that perceive BCtA tools have helped them improve their effectiveness and scale; Baseline (End of Year 2): -; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Achieved; July – Dec 2020 Target: Achieved
OUTPUT LEVEL Output 1: Increased number of high performing commitments Indicator 1.1: Number of potential member companies that BCtA has encouraged to consider IB annually; Baseline (End of Year 2): 759; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): 550; July – Dec 2020 Target: 600. Indicator 1.2: Number of BCtA companies (cumulative); Baseline (End of Year 2): 243; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): 257; July – Dec 2020 Target: 280. Indicator 1.3: Number of BCtA commitments (cumulative); Baseline (End of Year 2): 254; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): -; July – Dec 2020 Target: 292. Indicator 1.4: Number of companies using BCtA’s SDG and IB Maturity Journey and IB Management Practices Toolkit; Baseline (End of Year 2): Offline: 41 Online: 63 Total: 104; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): 126; July – Dec 2020 Target: 170. Indicator 1.5: Relevant role at critical global/regional events; Baseline (End of Year 2): 4; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Co-host at least 2 events, incl. Annual Forum; July – Dec 2020 Target: Co-host at least 1 event (online Annual Forum). Indicator 1.6: Selection process and criteria published; Baseline (End of Year 2): Applied; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Reviewed; July – Dec 2020 Target: -. Indicator 1.7: High performer category defined and implemented; Baseline (End of Year 2): Applied; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Applied and Reviewed; July – Dec 2020 Target: -. Indicator 1.8: Global media and event partnerships; Baseline (End of Year 2): 2 existing partnerships being implemented; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Partnerships reviewed and strengthened; July – Dec 2020 Target: -.
Output 2: Increased impact measurement and reporting Indicator 2.1: Interactive impact measurement toolkit; Baseline (End of Year 2): All 4 modules developed and launched; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): All 4 modules developed, publicly available and deployed; July – Dec 2020 Target: -. Indicator 2.2: Online and offline capacity-building on impact measurement using BCtA’s toolkit (cumulative indicator); Baseline (End of Year 2): 111 companies; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): 130 companies; July – Dec 2020 Target: 155 companies. Indicator 2.3: Percentage of required member companies who share their annual progress report; Baseline (End of Year 2): 67 percent; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Over 55 percent; July – Dec 2020 Target: Over 55 percent. Indicator 2.4: Collaboration with key players in the SDG measurement space; Baseline (End of Year 2): Collaborating with 4 key players in the SDG impact management space; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Collaboration reviewed and strengthened; July – Dec 2020 Target: Collaboration reviewed and strengthened.
Output 3: Documented evidence and analysis on how IB can be leveraged for the SDGs Indicator 3.1: Thought leadership contributions published; Baseline (End of Year 2): 1; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Develop and publish thought leadership contribution(s) including 5 selected cases documented; July – Dec 2020 Target: Develop and publish thought leadership contribution(s) including 5 selected cases documented. Indicator 3.2: Number of BCtA media contributions on IB (own and from others) (yearly indicators); Baseline (End of Year 2): 123 media contributions and 99 media mentions; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): 100; July – Dec 2020 Target: 130. Indicator 3.3: Benchmarking of progress and management practices; aggregation methodologies developed; Baseline (End of Year 2): Methodology developed; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Methodologies reviewed and applied; July – Dec 2020 Target: -. Indicator 4.2: Number of new commitments as a result of BCtA country-level engagement; Baseline (End of Year 2): 7; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): 6; July – Dec 2020 Target: 14. Indicator 4.3: Companies reached through online and offline capacity-building on SDG/IB Maturity Tool, Management Practices and Impact Measurement tools delivered in those countries; Baseline (End of Year 2): 68; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): 50; July – Dec 2020 Target: 55; Indicator 4.4: Country-level publications on IB’s contributions to SDG; Baseline (End of Year 2): -; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Nil; July – Dec 2020 Target: 1 country-level publication completed. Indicator 4.5: Number of SDG and IB public-private dialogues facilitated; Baseline (End of Year 2): -; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): 2 country-level dialogues facilitated; July – Dec 2020 Target: 1 country-level dialogue facilitated.

Outcome A: IB is recognized as an effective approach for achieving the SDGs Indicator: Recognition of IB as PS contribution to SDG global agenda (Yes/No); Baseline (End of Year 2): Yes; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Yes; Result (30 June 2020): Yes; July – Dec 2020 Target: Yes; Result (31 December 2020): Recognition through active engagement; Notes: Through its active engagement in relevant events at global and country level, as well as thought leadership and media presence, BCtA has actively contributed to the recognition of IB as a private sector-based contributor to the SDGs (including 539 attendees at the Annual Forum)
Indicator: Indicators to track IB models’ contribution to the SDGs defined; Baseline (End of Year 2): 40 indicators from SDGs developed and integrated into the Impact Lab; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Continued integration; Result (30 June 2020): Indicators developed in two service lines (new commitments and Impact Lab); July – Dec 2020 Target: Continued integration ; Result (31 December 2020): Indicators developed in additional service line (SDG Corporate Tracker); Notes: Gender-disaggregated reporting indicators under commitments made to by member companies implemented; COVID-19-sensitive indicators added to the SGD Corporate Tracker; Indicators reviewed as part to include gender-disaggregated impacts in the Impact Lab 2.0
Indicator: IB included by leading corporate sustainability standards as a measure of responsible business practices; Baseline (End of Year 2): Yes; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Yes; Result (30 June 2020): Contributing to this via BCtA’s tools (incl. the IB Management Practices tool and Impact Lab) and outreach; July – Dec 2020 Target: Yes; Result (31 December 2020): Contributing to this via BCtA’s tools (incl. the IB Management Practices tool and Impact Lab) and outreach; Notes: Continuously contributing to this outcome
Outcome B: The credibility of IBs results and integrity is improved Indicator: Evidence of IB contribution to SDGs improved; Baseline (End of Year 2): Evidence delivered; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Evidence delivered; Result (30 June 2020): Evidence delivered; July – Dec 2020 Target: Evidence delivered; Result (31 December 2020): Evidence delivered from 2019 results reporting and Impact Lab reporting; Notes: -
Indicator: Number of participating companies that adopt better impact measurement practices through BCtA tools and guidance; Baseline (End of Year 2): 91 companies using BCtA’s impact management approach (21 BIMS, 70 companies using the Impact Lab); Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): 130; Result (30 June 2020): 184; July – Dec 2020 Target: 155; Result (31 December 2020): 585; Notes: 21 companies through BIMS, 264 companies using the Impact Lab, and 307 reached through workshops
Indicator: Members and other stakeholders perceive improved credibility of IB commitments and BCtA’s membership and impact measurement support; Baseline (End of Year 2): Achieved; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Achieved; Result (30 June 2020): Achieved; July – Dec 2020 Target: Achieved; Result (31 December 2020): Achieved; Notes: Increased demands for BCtA’s services, including on Impact Measurement and Management from both UNDP Country Offices and partner organizations at the local and global level
Outcome C: IBs increase their effectiveness and scale Indicator: Members adopting good IB management practices; Baseline (End of Year 2): Typology validated; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Track good management practices and assess link with progress made; Result: Good management practices tracked and link with progress made assessed through IB Management Practices Tool; July – Dec 2020 Target: Track good management practices and assess link with progress made; Result (31 December 2020): Good management practices tracked and link with progress made assessed through IB Management Practices Tool; Notes: -
Indicator: Number of follow-on commitments; Baseline (End of Year 2): -; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): -; Result (30 June 2020): 4; July – Dec 2020 Target: -; Result (31 December 2020): 5; Notes: Direct Fresh, Pınar Dairy, Sevamob, Corpocampo and H&M
Indicator: Number of commitments that report growth; Baseline (End of Year 2): 92 percent in 2017 reporting; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): -; Result (30 June 2020): 94 percent in 2018 reporting; July – Dec 2020 Target: -; Result (31 December 2020): 95 percent in 2019 reporting; Notes: -
Indicator: Number of member companies that perceive BCtA tools have helped them improve their effectiveness and scale; Baseline (End of Year 2): -; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Achieved; Result (30 June 2020): Achieved; July – Dec 2020 Target: Achieved; Result (31 December 2020): Achieved; Notes: Evidence of impact of BCtA tools received; Companies engaged in the revision process of BCtA’s service lines and services designed in accordance with company demands
Output level Output 1: Increased number of high performing commitments Indicator 1.1: Number of potential member companies that BCtA has encouraged to consider IB annually; Baseline (End of Year 2): 759; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): 550; Result (30 June 2020): 1,557; July – Dec 2020 Target: 600; Result (31 December 2020): 2,790; Notes: Includes proportional figures for audiences reached through COVID-19-based webinars, which have been receiving large audiences
Indicator 1.2: Number of BCtA companies (cumulative); Baseline (End of Year 2): 243; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): 257; Result (30 June 2020): 257; July – Dec 2020 Target: 280; Result (31 December 2020): 280; Notes: 4 companies included in this total are currently waiting for RAT approval by UNDP HQ so that they can be submitted to the DSC but approval procedures were completed by BCtA in 2020. Indicator 1.3: Number of BCtA commitments (cumulative); Baseline (End of Year 2): 254; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): -; Result (30 June 2020): 271; July – Dec 2020 Target: 294; Result (31 December 2020): 290; Notes: - Indicator 1.4: Number of companies using BCtA’s SDG and IB Maturity Journey and IB Management Practices Toolkit; Baseline (End of Year 2): Offline: 41 Online: 63 Total: 104; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): 126; Result (30 June 2020): Offline: 52 Online: 74 Total: 126; July – Dec 2020 Target: 170; Result (31 December 2020): Offline/Webinars: 87 Online: 126 Total: 213; Notes: BCtA conducted workshops in Lagos (19 companies attending), Cairo (10), Utrecht (20), Istanbul (3) and online webinars (87); Online maturity diagnostics were used by 74 organizations (figures reported for December 2019)
Indicator 1.5: Relevant role at critical global/regional events; Baseline (End of Year 2): 4; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Co-host at least 2 events, incl. Annual Forum; Result (30 June 2020): Hosted or co-hosted 3 events, incl. Annual Forum; July – Dec 2020 Target: Co-host at least 1 event (online Annual Forum); Result (31 December 2020): Hosted or co-hosted 10 events, incl. annual forums; Notes: Organized 2019 Annual Forum on the sidelines of the 74th session of the UNGA and the 2020 Annual Forum via a web-based platform. Moderated a session in the CSR Summit in Bratislava. Participated as panellist in the First Regional SDG Summit in Astana, in the MENA BoP Summit in Cairo, and Business Fights Poverty event. Participated in the High-Level Political Forum side event “Foster business contribution to the SDGs at national level” presenting the SDG corporate Tracker in Colombia together with the Colombian National Government, GRI and Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Moderated a panel in the SDG Finance Geneva Summit. Organized and facilitated 3 panels at the UN Global Compact 20 years Leaders Summit. Organized two sessions in the ImpactFest in The Hague. Additionally, multiple webinars hosted and co-hosted on COVID-19 response.
Indicator 1.6: Selection process and criteria published; Baseline (End of Year 2): Applied; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Reviewed; Result (30 June 2020): Reviewed; July – Dec 2020 Target: -; Result (31 December 2020): Reviewed; Notes: New indicators with a specific focus on gender-based impact implemented and being employed by new member companies.
Indicator 1.7: High performer category defined and implemented; Baseline (End of Year 2): Applied; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Applied and reviewed; Result (30 June 2020): Applied and reviewed; July – Dec 2020 Target: -; Result (31 December 2020): Applied and reviewed; Notes: The Inclusive Management Practices Tool implemented and being used by a wide range of IBs in order to identify high performers
Indicator 1.8: Global media and event partnerships; Baseline (End of Year 2): 2 existing partnerships being implemented; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Partnerships reviewed and strengthened; Result (30 June 2020): Partnerships reviewed and strengthened; July – Dec 2020 Target: -; Result (31 December 2020): Partnerships reviewed and strengthened; Notes: -
Output 2: Increased impact measurement and reporting Indicator 2.1: Interactive impact measurement toolkit; Baseline (End of Year 2): All 4 modules developed and launched; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): All 4 modules developed, publicly available and deployed; Result (30 June 2020): Reached; July – Dec 2020 Target: -; Result (31 December 2020): Reached; Notes: The full version of the BCtA Impact Lab available for member companies and non-members to measure and manage impact on the SDGs. The toolkit has been revised following the roll-out and an updated version delivered. The tool was translated into Spanish and French. Besides, a new dashboard and a feature for screening companies based on the IMP methodology was added.
Indicator 2.2: Online and offline capacity-building on impact measurement using BCtA’s toolkit (cumulative indicator); Baseline (End of Year 2): 111 companies; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): 130 companies; Result (30 June 2020): 195 companies; July – Dec 2020 Target: 155 companies; Result (31 December 2020): 270 companies; Notes: Includes online and in-person workshops
Indicator 2.3: Percentage of required member companies who share their annual progress report; Baseline (End of Year 2): 67 percent; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Over 55 percent; Result (30 June 2020): 40 percent; July – Dec 2020 Target: Over 55 percent; Result (31 December 2020): 72 percent; Notes: The introduction of a new online process to transition members’ reporting into a company-led process that requires fewer inputs from the BCtA Team in 2019 experienced log-in and IT issues. However, following the pilot phase, this automated reported system increased the proportion of companies reporting in 2020.
Indicator 2.4: Collaboration with key players in the SDG measurement space; Baseline (End of Year 2): Collaborating with 4 key players in the SDG impact management space; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Collaboration reviewed and strengthened; Result (30 June 2020): Collaboration reviewed and strengthened; July – Dec 2020 Target: Collaboration reviewed and strengthened; Result (31 December 2020): Collaboration reviewed and strengthened; Notes: Partnerships with Innovation for Social Impact Partnership, imece, SDG Impact, the Impact Management Project, the Global Reporting Initiative, Acumen Fund and the Impact Hub strengthened
Output 3: Documented evidence and analysis on how IB can be leveraged for the SDGs Indicator 3.1: Thought leadership contributions published; Baseline (End of Year 2): 1; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Develop and publish thought leadership contribution(s) including 5 selected cases documented; Result (30 June 2020): 1 report, 28 blogs, 14 Guardian microsite stories and 11 webinars; July – Dec 2020 Target: Develop and publish thought leadership contribution(s) including 5 selected cases documented; Result (31 December 2020): 2 reports, 42 blogs, 19 Guardian microsite stories, 2 videos, 12 case studies and 12 webinars; Notes: What does it take to go big? Management practices to bring inclusive business to scale and WEF report: COVID-19 action agenda leaders on the frontline. Impact Report currently under development with Oxfam and IICPSD partner organizations and due for publication in early 2021; an IB operational guidelines paper is ongoing and under a consultancy with 15 organizations and iBAN; a White paper is being written on the replication of telehealth IB models; and a Tunisia IB Ecosystem Report currently under development and due for publication in early 2021.
Indicator 3.2: Number of BCtA media contributions on IB (own and from others) (yearly indicators); Baseline (End of Year 2): 123 media contributions and 99 media mentions; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): 100; Result (30 June 2020): 51 media contributions and 40 media mentions; July – Dec 2020 Target: 130; Result (31 December 2020): 163 (96 media contributions and 67 media mentions); Notes: -
Indicator 3.3: Benchmarking of progress and management practices; aggregation methodologies developed; Baseline (End of Year 2): Methodology developed; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Methodologies reviewed and applied; Result (30 June 2020): Methodologies reviewed and applied; July – Dec 2020 Target: -; Result (31 December 2020): Methodologies reviewed and applied; Notes: Benchmarking Tool integrated within the Inclusive Business Management Practices Tool; Data captured will help to create a stronger benchmarking tool for future users
Indicator 3.4: BCtA Communications/ Dissemination Strategy and Implementation Plan aligned with the Phase III and materials developed; Baseline (End of Year 2): Applied; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): ; Result (30 June 2020): Preparation of a communication plan-; July – Dec 2020 Target: Finalization of partnerships and communications strategy and action plan (PCAP); Result (31 December 2020): -; Notes: -
Output 4: Country-level mobilization of commitments towards SDG contributions Indicator 4.1: Number of country-level engagements; Baseline (End of Year 2): Bangladesh, Tunisia and LATAM: Colombia, Tunisia (focus countries) Honduras, Costa Rica (engagement to deliver services); Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): 2; July – Dec 2020 Target: 2; Result (30 June 2020): 2; Result (31 December 2020): 5 countries - 2 focus countries (Colombia and Tunisia) and 3 countries where BCtA delivered its services ( Philippines, Thailand, Turkey); Notes: -
Indicator 4.2: Number of new commitments as a result of BCtA country-level engagement; Baseline (End of Year 2): 7; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): 6; Result (30 June 2020): 6; July – Dec 2020 Target: 14; Result (31 December 2020): 13; Notes: Bangladesh: Euglena Co. Ltd. Colombia: Bavaria & Cía S.C.A., Brand Solutions, Cacao Nahua, Elepha S.A.S, Hogaru, Lohas Beans, PROST, and Takami S.A. (two other have RAT pending approval by HQ and are expected to be welcomed to BCtA in early 2021). Tunisia: Committed to Good and Redstart Tunisie. The below-target number of member companies is largely due to delays in the conduct of due diligence procedures and in-country issues related to the COVID-19 pandemic Indicator 4.3: Companies reached through online and offline capacity-building on SDG/IB Maturity Tool, Management Practices and Impact Measurement tools delivered in those countries; Baseline (End of Year 2): 68; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): 50; Result (30 June 2020): 66; July – Dec 2020 Target: 55; Result (31 December 2020): 157; Notes: The Philippines: 42 companies trained on impact measurement and management practices. Colombia: 41 companies trained on impact measurement and management practices and 5 as part of the Impact Champions Programme. Bangladesh: 1 company trained as part of the Impact Champions programme. Tunisia: 68 private sector stakeholders in gender masterclasses. Indicator 4.4: Country-level publications on IB’s contributions to SDG; Baseline (End of Year 2): -; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): Nil; Result (30 June 2020): Nil; July – Dec 2020 Target: 1 country-level publication completed; Result (31 December 2020): Nil; Notes: As a result of the postponement of the incorporation of Tunisia as a focus country, planned country-level publications were delayed. A publication on the Tunisian ecosystem is currently under development and is expected to be completed by February 2021. Indicator 4.5: Number of SDG and IB public-private dialogues facilitated; Baseline (End of Year 2): -; Year 3 Target (July 2019 – June 2020): 2 country-level dialogues facilitated. Result (30 June 2020): 2 (Colombia and Tunisia); July – Dec 2020 Target: 1 country-level dialogue facilitated; Result (31 December 2020): 5 (incl. Colombia and Tunisia); Notes: Scoping mission to Tunisia undertaken to strengthen partnerships with in-country actors, with a mapping and stakeholder consultation exercise now underway in Tunisia; and webinars/online discussions held on business response to the COVID-19 pandemic, gender equality and BCtA tools in Tunisia and Colombia; and webinars/online discussions held on business response to the COVID-19 pandemic, gender equality and BCtA tools with Tunisia and Colombia as key stakeholders through online roundtables and webinars (UNGC, HLPF, BCtA Annual Forum and webinars). Other public-private dialogues facilitated in the Philippines, Thailand, and Turkey.

Outcome indicators
Impact: IBs make a significant contribution to achieving the SDGs
Beneficiaries covered by the inclusive innovation process (e.g., through piloting the Inclusive Innovation process) (direct impact); Baseline (31 December 2020): To be tracked going forward; Target (for 31 December 2021): 60,000. Notes: Based on Inclusive Innovation reports
Total monetary investment by BCtA members into BCtA IB initiatives (indirect impact; non-cumulative); Baseline (31 December 2020): USD 275,142,812 (2019); Target (for 31 December 2021): N/A (indirect impact). Notes: -
Number of BoP individuals reached by membership (indirect impact) Baseline (31 December 2020): Improved access to goods and services: 125,612,461, Full-time jobs created: 43,165, People with increased productivity/ revenue-generating activities as a result of the initiative: 32,819,113, Tracked impact on women: 7,497,208, Total (2019): 233,909,164; Target (for 31 December 2021): N/A (indirect impact). Notes: Assessment based on: - Net number of people with improved access to goods and services, - Net number of full-time jobs created, - Net number of people with increased productivity/ revenue-generating activities as a result of the initiative
Outcome A: IB is recognized as an effective approach to achieving the SDGs
Number of formal innovation systems oriented towards the poor (e.g., through piloting the Inclusive Innovation process); Baseline (31 December 2020): To be tracked going forward; Target (for 31 December 2021): 2. Notes: Includes tracking to ensure 50% women engaged in adaptation processes
Number of public and private sector actors engaged in finding solutions to address the needs of the poor through IB; Baseline (31 December 2020): To be tracked going forward; Target (for 31 December 2021): 10. Notes: Number of people engaged in public-private dialogue about IB solutions that can support governments (e.g., number of people participating in the Planning and Solving Problems stages of the Inclusive Innovation Journey)
Outcome B: The credibility of IBs results and integrity is improved
Number of private sector actors with increased ability to integrate an understanding of measuring and managing impact on the SDGs into their strategy and operations; Baseline (31 December 2020): 357; Target (for 31 December 2021): 400. Notes: Self-guided Impact Lab users through metrics and KPI definition (past Module 2), plus participants in IMM trainings (including SDG impact enterprise standards) (i.e., users trained via the Impact Lab counted only as training participants). Indicator refined from 2020 logframe.
Outcome C: IBs increase their effectiveness and scale
Number of services made available in the Inclusive Innovation Process (e.g., through piloting the Inclusive Innovation Process); Baseline (31 December 2020): To be tracked going forward; Target (for 31 December 2021): 2. Notes: Based on Inclusive Innovation Process reports
Number of models replicated in the inclusive innovation-replication process (e.g., through piloting the Inclusive Innovation Process); Baseline (31 December 2020): To be tracked going forward; Target (for 31 December 2021): 2. Notes: Based on Inclusive Innovation Process reports
Number of member commitments that report growth; Baseline (31 December 2020): 95%; Target (for 31 December 2021): -. Notes: Based on member’s annual progress reports: Percentage of companies reporting “flourishing,” “on track” or “progressing slowly”
Output Indicators
Output 1: Increased number of high performing commitments
1.1 Total number of companies engaged in BCtAs member pipeline (disaggregated by gender sensitivity); Baseline (31 December 2020): 759; Target (for 31 December 2021): 800. Notes: BCtA Secretariat keeps track of the number on an ongoing basis and reviews the progress quarterly.
1.2 Number of BCtA companies (cumulative; disaggregated by gender sensitivity); Baseline (31 December 2020): 280; Target (for 31 December 2021): 300. Notes: BCtA Secretariat keeps track of membership on an ongoing basis, and reports semi-annually
1.3 Current number of active commitments (not cumulative; disaggregated by gender sensitivity); Baseline (31 December 2020): 84; Target (for 31 December 2021): 90. Notes: BCtA Secretariat keeps track of member commitments on an ongoing basis, and reports semi-annually; 78 active commitments expired at the end of 2020.
1.4 Number of participants reached through advocacy or convenings (cumulative for the Phase; disaggregated by gender-sensitive content); Baseline (31 December 2020): 2,790; Target (for 31 December 2021): 3,400. Notes: BCtA Secretariat keeps track of member commitments on an ongoing basis, and reports semi-annually; 78 of the 139 active commitments expire at the end of 2020
1.5 Relevant role at critical global/regional events for BCtA or BCtA members (cumulative for the Phase; disaggregated by gender-sensitive content); Baseline (31 December 2020): 10; Target (for 31 December 2021): 15. Notes: BCtA Secretariat keeps track of advocacy efforts on an ongoing basis, and reports semi-annually
Output 2: Increased capacity for impact
2.1 Number of BCtA tool users; Baseline (31 December 2020): To be tracked going forward; Target (for 31 December 2021): 300. Notes: BCtA Secretariat reports the updates at least annually; includes Impact Lab, IB Management Practices, and IB Maturity Tool
2.2 Number of active member communities of practice (cumulative for the Phase; disaggregated by gender); Baseline (31 December 2020): 2; Target (for 31 December 2021): 3. Notes: BCtA Secretariat reports the updates at least annually
2.3 Percentage of required member companies who share their annual progress report (not cumulative); Baseline (31 December 2020): Target: Over 67 percent, Achieved: 72 percent; Target (for 31 December 2021): Over 67 percent. Notes: BCtA Secretariat collects the progress report annually; based on active commitments. Targets defined according to previous December 2020 target.
2.4 Collaboration with partner organizations (cumulative for the Phase); Baseline (31 December 2020): 5; Target (for 31 December 2021): 5. Notes: BCtA Secretariat reports the updates at least annually; active collaborations (e.g., business accelerators, investors, knowledge partners). Baseline IMM-related partners: imece, UNDP’s ImpactAim, ISIP, Boost, and Youth Co:Lab. Other institutional partners: AGFund, IFC, Oxfam, WEF.
2.5 Number of country-level activities where IMM is scaling on a cost-recovery basis, aligned with SDG Impact enterprise standards (cumulative for the Phase); Baseline (31 December 2020): To be tracked going forward; Target (for 31 December 2021): 3. Notes: BCtA Secretariat reports the updates at least annually
2.6 Number of participants trained on BCtAs tools (cumulative for the Phase); Baseline (31 December 2020): To be tracked going forward; Target (for 31 December 2021): 180. Notes: BCtA Secretariat reports the updates at least annually; includes training for trainers and users. Disaggregated by trainers trained and other participants
Output 3: Documented evidence and analysis on how IB can be leveraged for the SDGs
3.1 Thought-leadership contributions produced (cumulative for the Phase); Baseline (31 December 2020): 3; Target (for 31 December 2021): 4. Notes: BCtA Secretariat keeps track of the publications and case studies published and reviews the progress quarterly; includes methodologies, sector intelligence briefs developed to determine replication and adaptation challenges for inclusive innovation processes, reports on inclusive innovation learning, (including impact monetization), case studies, working papers commissioned research or tools. Baseline formed of two reports and one case study set.
3.2 Number of BCtA media contributions on IB (own and from others) (cumulative for the Phase); Baseline (31 December 2020): 485; Target (for 31 December 2021): 360. Notes: BCtA Secretariat keeps track of media contributions and reports progress semi-annually; includes media material developed by BCtA or about BCtA. Based on the production of content and replication of BCtA mentions calculated through retweets, shares, web analytics, impressions and engagement. Calculated cumulatively starting from 2020 as a revised indicator.
3.3 Reach of media contributions on different channels (cumulative for the Phase); Baseline (31 December 2020): To be tracked going forward; Target (for 31 December 2021): 8,000. Notes: BCtA Secretariat keeps track of media contributions and reports progress semi-annually; includes impressions in different channels
Output 4: Country-level mobilization of commitments towards SDG contributions
4.1 Number of country-level engagements (e.g. piloting the Inclusive Innovation Process) (cumulative for the Phase); Baseline (31 December 2020): 2; Target (for 31 December 2021): 2. Notes: BCtA Secretariat reports the updates at least annually; number of countries with an active innovation journey during the reporting period
4.2 Number of local private sector actors engaged in the inclusive innovation processes (e.g. through piloting the Inclusive Innovation Process) (cumulative for the Phase); Baseline (31 December 2020): To be tracked going forward; Target (for 31 December 2021): 4. Notes: BCtA Secretariat reports updates at least annually
4.3 Number of SDG and IB public-private dialogues facilitated (e.g. through piloting the Inclusive Innovation Process) (cumulative for the Phase); Baseline (31 December 2020): To be tracked going forward; Target (for 31 December 2021): 4. Notes: BCtA Secretariat reports updates at least annually.
4.4 Number of public sector agents and policymakers trained on and/or engaged in inclusive innovation processes (e.g. through piloting the Inclusive Innovation Process) (cumulative for the Phase; disaggregated by gender); Baseline (31 December 2020): To be tracked going forward; Target(for 31 December 2021): 20. Notes: BCtA Secretariat reports the updates at least annually; based on participant tracking (e.g., number of public sector actors by department, function, gender) and participant surveys to gauge increased capacity.

Outcome indicators
Impact: IBs make a significant contribution to achieving the SDGs Beneficiaries covered by the inclusive innovation process (e.g., through piloting the Inclusive Innovation process) (direct impact); Baseline (31 December 2020): To be tracked going forward; Target (for 31 December 2021): 60,000. Number of BoP individuals reached by membership (indirect impact) Baseline (31 December 2020): Improved access to goods and services: 125,612,461, Full-time jobs created: 43,165, People with increased productivity/ revenue-generating activities as a result of the initiative: 32,819,113, Tracked impact on women: 7,497,208, Total (2019): 233,909,164. Output Indicators
Output 1: Increased number of high performing commitments
Total number of companies engaged in BCtAs member pipeline (disaggregated by gender sensitivity); Baseline (31 December 2020): 759; Target (for 31 December 2021): 800, Results achieved: 819. Notes: Companies who reached out to BCtA through online eligibility form and website e-mail request are included.
1.2 Number of BCtA companies (cumulative; disaggregated by gender sensitivity); Baseline (31 December 2020): 280; Target (for 31 December 2021): 300, Results achieved: 284 (as of Nov 2021). Notes: 10 companies with RATs approved by UNDP. 114 of 284 made commitments against SDG 5.
1.3 Current number of active commitments (not cumulative; disaggregated by gender sensitivity); Baseline (31 December 2020): 84; Target (for 31 December 2021): 90, Results achieved: 99. Notes: 78 active commitments expired at the end of 2020. BCtA Secretariat keeps track of member commitments on an ongoing basis and reports semi-annually; 78 active commitments expired at the end of 2020. 2 recommitments made in the first quarter of 2021 (both have an SDG 5 focus), 8 recommitments made in May (6 have an SDG 5 focus), 3 additional recommitments made in June (all have SDG 5 focus), 45 of 97 active commitments (46.4%) have an SDG 5 focus.
1.4 Number of participants reached through advocacy or convenings (cumulative for the Phase; disaggregated by gender-sensitive content); Baseline (31 December 2020): 2,790; Target (for 31 December 2021): 3,400, Results achieved: 4,034. Notes: 78 of the 139 active commitments expire at the end of 2020. 2021 advocacy composed of the 8th Business Leaders Caucus, The IB Operational Guidelines Working Group, the WEF Non-Financial Support Working Group (including the sub-group on Unusual Pioneers), a UNDP X EDBI Sustainability Presentation, an imece event, a presentation to UNDP CO Philippines, a SF Geneva event, and a working group on Global Partnerships for effective development cooperation, and Annual Forum (800), ImpactFest, EVPA,
1.5 Relevant role at critical global/regional events for BCtA or BCtA members (cumulative for the Phase; disaggregated by gender-sensitive content); Baseline (31 December 2020): 10; Target (for 31 December 2021): 15, Results achieved: 17. Notes: HLPF 2021 Official Side-Event | The key role of innovative partnerships and transparency for the SDGs | Enel, UNDP Business Call to Action & GRI, World Humanitarian Forum, ISIP Summit, GRI Business Leadership Forum, UNDP Philippines - Webinar 5 Activity Design, UNDP’s Arab States regional Youth Leadership Programme (#YLP7); EVPA.

Notes: BCtA Secretariat reports the updates at least annually; includes Impact Lab, IB Management Practices, and IB Maturity Tool. Impact Lab: 436, IB Management Practices: 228, IB Maturity Tool: 197.
